Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Undergraduate Research in Molecular Genetics and Proteomics
Award.AbstractNarration: An award has been made to the University of Minnesota that will provide research training for 10 weeks for 10 students, during the summers of 2011- 2013. The program focuses on the use of molecular genetics and proteomics tools to address important research problems in gene structure, genome organization and regulation of gene expression in a variety of model systems. Student projects will be conducted under the direction of faculty members who are affiliated with the program. Students will spend the first 3 weeks of the summer program in an intensive 3-credit lab course at the Itasca Biological Station learning basic molecular genetics techniques and at a Proteomics Workshop. Students will then spend 7 weeks on the Twin Cities campus in a faculty laboratory working full time on an independent research project using techniques learned in the course. Additional program activities will include research presentations at weekly student seminars, participation in bioethics workshops, and participation in evening sessions designed to strengthen future applications for graduate studies. Students will be recruited at national meetings, during campus visits, and through the NSF and program web sites. Students will be selected based on academic record, letters of recommendation, personal statement, and potential for outstanding research in the biological sciences. Students will be tracked after the program to follow their eventual career paths. The program will be assessed through student and faculty surveys and by use of the REU common assessment tool. More information is available by visiting http://www.cbs.umn.edu/main/summer_research/ or by contacting the PI (Dr. Janet Schottel at schot002@umn.edu).

POR.DRECONTENT:
The NSF REU Site in Molecular Genetics and Proteomics at the University of Minnesota supported a total of 41 students in the summers of 2011, 2012, 2013, and 2014. The goal of the REU site was to motivate and prepare students to pursue graduate degrees in the life sciences. Students were selected based on academic record, letters of recommendation, personal statement, and potential for outstanding research in the biological sciences. In particular, underrepresented minority students, disadvantaged students and women who were early in their college careers and from schools with a large minority population or with limited research opportunities were invited to participate. Students were recruited at national meetings, during campus visits, and through the NSF and program web sites.

This REU program was focused on the use of molecular genetics and proteomics tools to address important research problems in gene structure, genome organization and regulation of gene expression in a variety of model systems. Students spent the first 3 weeks of the summer program in an intensive 3-credit lab course at the Itasca Biological Station & Laboratories learning basic molecular genetics techniques and at a Proteomics Workshop held on the Twin Cities campus. Students spent the remaining 7 weeks of the program on the Twin Cities campus in a faculty laboratory working full time on an independent research project using techniques learned in the course.

Additional program activities included research presentations at weekly student seminars lead by a current graduate student coordinator, participation in bioethics workshops, GRE preparation, and participation in evening sessions designed to strengthen future applications for graduate studies. Students prepared and presented a professional poster at the all-campus life sciences poster session at the end of the program to highlight their research findings.

Forty-one students participated in this REU site during the past four summers. There were 25 women and 16 men. Most of the students were early in their college career: 18 completed their freshman year, 22 completed their sophomore year, and one completed their junior year. With regard to diversity, 63% of the students were underrepresented minority students. Students experienced cutting-edge research by carrying out independent projects, collaborating with members of their laboratory, and presenting their results to peers. Students were encouraged to present the results of their work at local and national scientific conferences and to pursue advanced graduate degrees and research careers in the biological sciences.

The NSF REU common assessment survey was used to evaluate the program each summer. Since younger students were involved in the REU program over the past four summers, the analysis of their career paths is not complete at this time; tracking their progress after program participation is an ongoing effort. More information about this REU site is available by visiting http://www.cbs.umn.edu/lssurp.
